metadata.title: Capsid integrity quantitative PCR to determine virus infectivity in 1 environmental and food applications -a systematic review 2 3 Mats Leifels

abstract.text: Capsid-integrity quantitative PCR (qPCR), a molecular detection method for infectious viruses 21 combining azo-dye pretreatment with qPCR, has been widely used in recent years; however, 22 variations in pretreatment conditions for various virus types can limit the efficacy of specific 23 protocols. By identifying and critically synthesizing forty-two recent peer-reviewed studies 24 employing capsid-integrity qPCR for viruses in the last decade (2009 to 2019) in the fields of food 25 safety and environmental virology, we aimed to establish recommendations for the detection of 26 infectious viruses. Intercalating dyes are effective measures of viability in PCR assays provided 27 the viral capsid is damaged; viruses that have been inactivated by other causes, such as loss of 28 attachment or genomic damage, are less well detected using this approach. Although optimizing 29 specific protocols for each virus is recommended, we identify a framework for general assay 30 conditions. These include concentrations of ethidium monoazide, propidium monoazide or its 31 derivates between 10 and 200 µM; incubation on ice or at room temperature (20 -25ºC) for 5 to 32 120 min; and dye activation using LED or high light (500 -800 Watts) exposure for periods 33 ranging from 5 to 20 min. These simple steps can benefit the investigation of infectious virus 34 transmission in routine (water) monitoring settings and during viral outbreaks such as the current 35 COVID-19 pandemic or endemic diseases like dengue fever.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 12, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.08.20095364 doi: medRxiv preprint One of the most established qPCR modifications to measure infectivity is capsid integrity qPCR, 76 an approach where samples are pre-treated with the intercalating azo dyes propidium monoazide 77 (PMA), ethidium monoazide (EMA) or their derivates PMAxx and PEMAX. First described 78 almost two decades ago by Nogva et al. (2003) to allow the identification of viable but non-79 cultivable bacteria, this technique has been successfully adapted to remove putatively false- viable measurement method has been especially useful for those viruses for which cell cultivation-
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: based detection has been difficult, but has yet to be fully validated (Estes et al., 2019) . One known 89 limitation of the azo intercalating dyes is their inability to differentiate viruses that have lost their 90 infectivity due to damaged nucleic acids but whose capsid remains intact, a condition often found 91 after UV-C treatment (Leifels et al., 2015) . Moreover, there are numerous factors that affect the 92 efficacy of a method, including virus type, inactivation method, type of dye and its concentration.
Incubation conditions and light source are also crucial in the applicability of capsid integrity qPCR 94 as reflected by the great range of capsid integrity pretreatment conditions in the literature.

Consequently, the objectives of this review were to evaluate the efficiency of azo dye pretreatment 96 conditions as stated in current literature and to establish protocols and considerations of the capsid 97 integrity qPCR methods for virus infectivity monitoring.

118 Figure 2 : Schematic overview of a typical case study structure. One or more virus samples (taken from the 119 environment or a culture collection) are split in two and one portion is inactivated, the other not, before 120 filtration and concentration steps. Azo-dye pretreatment is then conducted under various incubation 121

conditions and concentrations of PMA, PMAxx, PEMAX or EMA, either in the presence or absence of 122 additives like surfactants and enzymes, before the tubes are exposed to light for photo activation. While 123 early studies used high-energy light sources (500 -800 Watt) to initiate the formation of the light induced 124
dye-genome complex, more recent articles have focused on low energy LED in the blue light spectrum. 125

FIGREF0.text: . Due to their high infectivity and transmission rate as well as usually relatively low 57 infectious dose, virus analysis in water and on fomites is frequently used when investigating 58 likelihood of water-/surface borne transmission. This is especially the case in viral outbreaks 59 causing acute and chronic illnesses like the Ebola virus disease, severe acute respiratory syndrome 60 (SARS), Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (Mers), seasonal dengue outbreaks in (sub-)tropical 61 regions and the current COVID-19 pandemic caused by SARS-Coronavirus-2 (Corman et al., 62 2020; Grubaugh et al., 2019)). 63 While still the gold standard, culture-based methods for propagation of infectious human 64 pathogenic viruses in a laboratory environment require specialized facilities and experienced 65 personnel and test results may only become available after five to ten days (Rodriguez et al., 2009).

FIGREF1.text: Molecular techniques using quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) are faster and have 67 been successfully used in the past two decades to determine virus loads in the aquatic environment 68 and to comply with food safety regulations (Bosch et al., 2018; Gerba and Betancourt, 2019). 69 While robust, cost-efficient and uniquely sensitive and specific, qPCR has the severe limitation of 70 not being able to differentiate between infectious and non-infectious virus particles, thus 71 overestimating the number of viruses present in a sample (Chhipi-Shrestha et al., 2017). Novel 72 approaches like modifying the targeted gene sequence or the length of the PCR product, or 73 amplifying less stable messenger RNA after reverse transcription to DNA (e.g. (Ho et al., 2016; 74 Ko et al., 2003; Polston et al., 2014; Wu et al., 2019)) generally lack robustness and sensitivity.

FIGREF2.text: 80 positive qPCR signals deriving from virions with broken capsids in complex matrices like sewage 81 and surface water (Leifels et al., 2016; Randazzo et al., 2018a). Based on the principle that an azo 82 dye can only enter virions with a damaged capsid to covalently and irreversibly bind with viral 83 DNA or RNA, this pretreatment can block amplification of nucleic acids due to the detachment of 84 the polymerase when it encounters the dye-genome complex. Subsequently, only genomic targets 85 are amplified that originate from intact virions while those nucleic acids that are free (outside the 86 virion) or belong to non-infectious viruses are removed from the quantitative PCR. This indirect 87

To ensure101 reproducibility, a search string was constructed in accordance with the Cochrane Handbook 102 (Cochrane, 2019), and a search was conducted in March 2020 (Figure 1) in relevant databases like 103 Pubmed, Scopus, Ovid, Medline and Web of Knowledge to cover relevant articles in English since 104 the first introduction of the azo dye pretreatment in 2003 (Supplementary

FIGREF4.text: PRISMA flowchart of the literature search strategy and the number of included and 108 excluded articles 109 110 For quality control and to follow the recommendations of Cochrane (2019), two of the authors 111 (M.L. and K.S.) conducted the title and abstract evaluation in parallel, with a third author (E.S.) 112 acting as tie breaker in the case of disagreement. As depicted in Figure 2, the 42 articles represented 113 .

FIGREF6.text: utilized in water treatment or food safety have also used capsid integrity 129 qPCR to determine the efficiency in virus inactivation (Lee et al., 2018; Leifels et al., 2015; 130 Randazzo et al., 2018b).

FIGREF8.text: Genus and strain number of viruses investigated and frequency of occurrence in case 138 studies (in parentheses). In cases where no strain name was listed, the virus is referred to as 'not 139 specified'.

FIGREF9.text: of studies investigated two or more viruses (69%) with an emphasis on the detection 142 of norovirus GI and GII (NoV GI/NoV GII) together with hepatitis A virus (HAV). The increase 143 in the number of studies on capsid integrity of NoV's and HAV between 2016 and 2020 is most 144 likely associated with the release of ISO/TS 15216-2:2013 (ISO, 2013) that regulates the 145 quantification of NoV and HAV using qPCR, and subsequently has been replaced with an updated 146 version (ISO, 2019). The risk associated with norovirus outbreaks due to a low infectious dose and 147 high rate of particle shedding by infected individuals, together with the absence of commercially 148 available animal tissue cell lines, also explains the interest in developing azo dye pretreatments for 149 the detection of NoV (Blanco et al., 2017; Lowther et al., 2019). Murine norovirus (MNV) and 150 mengovirus, two viruses without relevance to human health, have been chosen as both are widely 151 used as process control surrogates because they lack human pathogenicity and are easy to 152 propagate on certain cell lines. Of the articles included, only three cover bacteriophages infecting 153 coliform bacteria as their host (phages MS2, PhiX174 and T4). As the laboratory safety 154 requirements, as well as workload for culture-based detection, of those phages are significantly 155 lower than for enteric viruses, the necessity to establish alternative methods to determine phage 156 infectivity is not as urgent as for enteric viruses (Toribio-Avedillo et al., 2020). Their increasing 157 relevance in the context of microbial source tracking will likely lead to more studies in the future 158 (Ogilvie et al., 2018).

FIGREF10.text: 160exceptions. Bacteriophage T4 infecting Escherichia coli required higher temperatures for 161 inactivation than other viruses, with extremely high heat (110ºC) for significant capsid damage; 162 lower temperatures (85ºC) and proteolysis were not effective(Fittipaldi et al., 2012). Moreover,

FIGREF11.text: et al., 2015). Lack of efficacy of an azo dye method with avian influenza 166 virus was suspected to be due to natural characteristics of an enveloped virus that make it difficult 167 for EMA to penetrate the compromised capsid (Graiver et al., 2010). However, the PMA dye assay 168 was successfully applied to detect dengue virus, another enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus 169 (Huang et al., 2016), lending further support to the conclusion that PMA is more effective than 170 EMA in removing false positive signals in qPCR (Fittipaldi et al., 2012; Gedalanga and Olson, 171 2009; Leifels et al., 2019).

FIGREF12.text: analyzed were split evenly between strains obtained from culture-collections and wild 175 types, those obtained from clinical, environmental and food samples(Table 1). While progress has 176 been made in introducing protocols for their propagation in the laboratory, an established cell line 177 to propagate NoV GI/GII has yet to arrive (Estes et al., 2019; Veronica et al., 2018). Subsequently, 178 the studies included in this review analyzed NoV in stool samples obtained from hospitals, in 179 sewage or in surface water. One study evaluated the presence of NoV GI/GII in struvite, a 180 phosphate source used for fertilization, that was reclaimed from wastewater sludge (Yee et al., 181 2019). A limitation of all studies on clinical, environmental and food samples is the absence of 182 information regarding absolute quantification of infectious and non-infectious viruses to evaluate 183 the assay performance. Other complicating factors include process recovery loss and inhibition 184effects in qPCR assays that appeared to affect RNA viruses more than DNA viruses regardless of

FIGREF13.text: 199 most likely due to their higher ability to enter thermally and chemically inactivated cells (Jeong 200 et al., 2017; Kim et al., 2017; Moreno et al., 2015), when compared to infectious virus titers 201 determined by cell culture (Leifels et al., 2019). 202 Azo dye concentrations are quite evenly distributed, ranging from less than 10 µM to greater than 203 200 µM. More than half of the articles under investigation reported either 50 µM or 100 µM (Table 204 1), which is in accordance with the recommendations by the manufacturer for bacterial cultures 205 (Biotium Inc., 2019). However, some works indicated optimal reduction rates with dye 206 concentrations between 4 µM and 10 µM (Karim et al., 2015; Lee et al., 2016; Leifels et al., 2016; 207 Leifels et al., 2019; Prevost et al., 2016). The effect of high azo dye concentration appeared to vary 208 with virus type; for example, adverse effects have been reported with > 125 µM PMA and phage

FIGREF14.text: thirds of the studies included in this review applied an incubation time with 214 the azo dye of 5 or 10 min(Table 1). A quarter incubated for 30 min and less than one in ten of 215 the studies reported periods lasting longer than one hour. A similarly clear trend is observed for 216 incubation temperature; most studies incubated at temperatures between 20°C and 25°C or 217 indicated that room temperature was used(Table 1). The remainder of the articles described the218 samples being stored on ice or at 4 to 6°C; none of them used higher temperatures as sometimes 219 discussed for bacterial assays (Codony et al., 2019). Studies that applied a long incubation time 220 tended to use low temperatures (Coudray-Mounier et al., 2013; Sangsanont et al, 2014; Prevost et 221 al., 2016; Leifels et al., 2016; Canh et al., 2018; Oristo et al., 2017; Fraisse et al., 2018; Canh et 222 al., 2019; Leifels et al.utilizing azo dyes for the removal of non-infectious virus particles exclusively 226 applied 500-to 800-Watt halogen light sources used in stage lighting (Bellehumeur et al., 2015; 227 Canh et al., 2018; Escudero-Abarca et al., 2014; Graiver et al., 2010; Leifels et al., 2015; 228 Parshionikar et al., 2010; Sangsanont et al., 2014). Besides their operational hazards such as light 229 bulbs exploding due to long running times (a maximum of 5 min is recommended by the 230 manufacturer), both the heat and light emission in the ultraviolet and infrared spectra could 231 potentially harm the sample, thus subverting the purpose of the pretreatment altogether. consumer-grade LED light technology in general and the introduction of dedicated 233 azo dye activation light sources by companies like GenIUL, Spain, allowed for a much more 234 precise and reproducible activation of PMA, EMA, PEMAX and PMAxx. Not surprisingly, 72% 235 of the records included in this review utilized either the commercial LED Active Blue light system 236 (GenIUL, Spain) or LEDs emitting blue (around 460 nm) light (Lee et al. (2015); Fongaro et al. 237 (2016)) as depicted in Table 1. A similar trend towards uniformity in the protocol design is 238 apparent in the length of time a sample is exposed to the light source. While the operational 239 requirements of the 500-to 800-W halogen lamps severely limited the exposure time to very short 240 periods (2-5 minutes according to manufacturer's recommendations to avoid excessive heat 241 development that could lead to the light bulb exploding), the standard configuration of the 242 commercial light systems allows for 15 min of intense blue light. Two thirds of the studies 243 therefore employed 15 min as the light exposure time. 244 245 8. Additional reagents for azo dye pretreatment 246 Addition of non-ionic surfactants like Triton X-100 (Coudray-Meunier et al., 2013; Moreno et al., 247 2015) and sodium lauroyl sarcosinate (Lee et al., 2019; Lee et al., 2018) have been described as 248 beneficial for the determination of virus infectivity and were most frequently used in the studies 249 evaluated (Table 1). Inclusion of non-ionic surfactant enable the azo dye molecules to enter 250 partially or completely ruptured capsids, thus improving their binding properties in the virus 251 genome. Palladium and platinum compounds such as Platinum(IV) chloride (PtCl4) and Cis-252 dichlorodiammineplatinum (CPPD) are long known to chelate in mammalian cells by nucleic acid 253 ligands (Rosenberg et al., 1965), and have recently been adopted for the qPCR based 254 discrimination between live and dead bacteria such as E. coli and Cronobacter skazakii (Soejima 255 .

FIGREF15.text: to inactivate viruses were used in the studies included in this review. The 261 intention was either to evaluate disinfection efficiency as it is currently used in food safety and 262 water treatment (Jeong et al., 2017; Langlet et al., 2018; Leifels et al., 2016; Randazzo et al., 263 2018a) or to act as controls to evaluate the efficacy of the capsid integrity protocol (Canh et al., 264 2018; Canh et al., 2019; Farkas et al., 2020; Leifels et al., 2015). Addition of chlorine, exposure to 265 heat, and proteolysis are known to damage the viral capsid, thus rendering the genome accessible 266 to azo dyes. Temperatures from moderate to high (45°C to 95°C) for ten to thirty minutes could 267 reproducibly demonstrate the ability of all dyes to remove virus signals (to varying degrees) from 268 molecular quantification (Fraisse et al., 2018; Jeong et al., 2017; Leifels et al., 2015; Leifels et al., 269 2019; Oristo et al., 2018). Similar effects could be shown for the addition of hypochlorite of up to 270 two milligram per milliliter (Fuster et al., 2016; McLellan et al., 2016; Prevost et al., 2016). Light 271 in the ultraviolet spectrum, on the other hand, affects the hydrogen bonds between nucleic acids, 272 resulting in the inability to reproduce inside the host cell. Capsid integrity qPCR failed to capture 273 the loss of virus infectivity in most UV studies (Karim et al., 2015; Kim et al., 2017; Leifels et al., 274 2016; Leifels et al., 2019); it could detect capsid damage caused by medium-pressure UV lamps, 275 especially at 230-245 nm wavelength (Sangsanont et al., 2014), but not nucleic acid damage caused 276 by other wavelengths in the UV range (Beck et al., 2018; Beck et al., 2014; Sirikanchana et al., 277 2008a, b). The varying efficiencies of PMA, PMAxx, PEMAX and EMA in preventing the DNA/RNA of viruses that have lost their ability to infect their host cells due to 279 exposure to heat and reactive substances like chlorine resemble what has been described for 280 bacteria, starting with the first publication on the subject (Nogva et al.of azo dye pretreatment can be recommended for applications where culture assays 284 take too long to inform necessary remedial actions, and under low resource conditions either in 285 developing countries or in laboratories with only basic analytical capabilities. The recent outbreak 286 of SARS-CoV-2 associated COVID-19 represents an example where knowing the ratio of 287 infectious to non-infectious virions would help in determining whether symptomatic or 288 asymptomatic carriers need to be isolated (Beeching et al., 2020; Kaul, 2020). A step-by-step 289 protocol introducing azo-dye pretreatment to determine capsid integrity (and thus virus infectivity) 290 into an established qPCR workflow can be developed (Figure 4) according to the guidelines 291 suggested in this review. The key steps are virus-and matrix-specific optimization of the 292 incubation conditions, dye-concentration and photo activation.

FIGREF16.text: Design of a capsid-integrity qPCR assay. Depending on the sample origin (especially 296 the complexity of the matrix), the virus genus and strain as well as the molecular detection method 297 used, several factors like dilution of the sample, concentration of the azo-dye, incubation 298 .

FIGREF17.text: of methods on the application of azo dye pretreatment to determine virus infectivity 306 by qPCR revealed a great diversity of viruses that have been tested under a range of treatment 307 conditions. The systematic literature comparison led to the following conclusions: 308  PMA and the derivate PMAxx show a higher efficiency in removing false negative signals 309 from qPCR for both DNA and RNA viruses than EMA and PEMAX.

FIGREF18.text: Incubation duration and temperature, reagent concentration as well as light source and 311 exposure time need to be optimized and validated for the virus under investigation.

FIGREF19.text: "One size fits all" pretreatment approaches are possible but might lead to reduced signal 313 reduction rates of individual viruses. Capsid integrity qPCR can be a valuable tool to adapt existent workflows and qPCR 315 protocols to reflect the ability of viruses to infect humans, thus improving risk assessment 316 and consumer safety derived from these measurements. Capsid integrity is a strong indicator of virus infectivity, which allows for the establishment 318 of robust assays to assess the infectivity of novel viruses in the event of outbreaks like the 319 2014 Ebola virus epidemic and the current COVID-19 pandemic.
